Hydrogen spillover has been widely used in heterogeneous catalysis, yet how to explore the potential of catalyst support to further promote catalytic function of hydrogen spillover has rarely been investigated. Herein, platinum encapsulated into amorphized HA zeolite (denoted as Pt@HA) with generated hydroxyl groups was used as model catalyst to study the role of HA zeolite support on the promotion of catalytic performance in hydrogenation of quinolines to tetrahydroquinolines. Benefiting from small pore size of amorphized HA zeolite to prevent direct interaction of quinoline with encapsulated platinum, Pt@HA showed good catalytic selectivity in this transformation through hydrogen spillover. This remarkable catalytic selectivity was resulted from the interaction of hydroxyl groups at surface of HA zeolite with pyridine moiety through the formation NH bond to facilitate adsorption to make much lower apparent activation energy of Pt@HA for hydrogenation of pyridine moiety than that of benzene moiety, thus exhibiting enhanced catalytic selectivity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydrogen spillover HA zeolite Encapsulation Catalytic selectivity Support Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen spillover is a well-known phenomenon in heterogeneous catalysis, which involves the hydrogen dissociation on active metal surface to give activated hydrogen (H) atoms, followed by these active H species migrating from hydrogen-rich metal particles to “inert” support materials where hydrogen molecular cannot be dissociated [1–5]. Clearly, in this process, hydrogen can be activated and dissociated at one location, and consequent hydrogenation reaction step can happen at another location. Since the first discovery by Khoobiar in the early 1960s, hydrogen spillover has attracted considerable attention of many scientists to use the principle of this phenomenon to design efficient catalysts with enhanced catalytic properties [6–11]. For instance, Zheng group dispersed Pd atom onto Cu(100) support as a catalyst to make the occurrence of hydrogen spillover, and found that dissociated H atoms on Pd surface can easily spill over the Cu(100) to promote the semi-hydrogenation of various alkynes with enhanced high activity and selectivity. Interestingly, the hydrogen spillover from Pd to Cu was facet independent, and spillover hydrogenation can only proceed on Cu(100) instead of Cu(111) [12]. Qu group realized highly selective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde to cinnamyl alcohol through hydrogen spillover at room temperature over PtCo alloy supported on CoBOx, rather than other supports such as CeO2 and carbon black [13,14]. As shown, the kind of support structure plays a critical role to achieve spillover hydrogenation. Historically, scientists agreed on the occurrence of hydrogen spillover on reducible support, on which, the dissociated H atom can migrate as a pair of H + and e −, yet whether existence of hydrogen spillover on nonreducible support remained questionable [15–17]. As the development of controllable synthesis methodology combined with advanced characterization technique, at present, researchers have established that hydrogen spillover can also take place on nonreducible support, such as silica, aluminum oxide, zeolite and so on [18–20]. For example, Choi et al. synthesized platinum encapsulated into dense aluminosilicate matrix as model catalyst to study the catalytic function of hydrogen spillover. They found that hydrogen spillover can occur on this nonreducible aluminosilicate encapsulated catalyst to facilitate the chemoselective dehydrogenation of propane to propylene through the key of surface hydroxyl to initiate H spillover [18]. Karim et al. prepared a series of model catalysts of platinum-iron oxide nanoparticles pairs with varying distances placed onto nonreducible Al2O3 support through electron beam lithography methods, and a distance-dependent hydrogen spillover behavior was observed by hydrogen atoms spilled from Pt particles to Al2O3 support [19]. Notably, although the nature of support for spillover hydrogenation has been extensively elucidated and explored, however, how to utilize promotion effect of support to strengthen the spillover process to enhance catalytic function remains limited [21]. To realize the aforementioned objective on the support not only to facilitate the occurrence of hydrogen spillover but also to promote the catalytic function of hydrogen spillover, herein, taking calcinated NH4-exchanged NaA zeolite as support, the catalytic performance of this support encapsulated Pt clusters catalyst in selective hydrogenation of quinoline to 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline was investigated. As designed, on one hand, calcinated NH4-exchanged NaA zeolite possessing many hydroxyl groups can ensure the taking place of hydrogen spillover. On the other hand, the existed hydroxyls could interact with pyridine moiety of quinoline compound through the formation N-H bond to strengthen the hydrogenation step of spilled H atoms with activated pyridine moiety to give desired product. As expected, such synthesized encapsulated catalyst exhibited approaching 100% selectivity to desired 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline in the hydrogenation of quinoline, along with good stability without leaching of Pt. Control experiments combined with DFT calculation indicated that positive effect of HA zeolite support to strengthen the activation of reactant via hydroxyl groups played the critical roles for the promotion of catalytic function of hydrogen spillover in the hydrogenation of quinoline compound. 2 Experimental procedures 2.1 Reagents and materials Sodium metaaluminate (NaAlO2, Al2O3: 55%, Na2O: 42.5%, Macklin), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 98.5%, Acros), polyethylene glycol (PEG, average M.W. 1450, Acros), Ludox-AS 30 colloidal silica (30 wt.% SiO2 in water, Sigma-Aldrich), ammonium chloride (NH4Cl, 99.5%, Aladdin), (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane (95%, Sigma-Aldrich), chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O, ≥ 37.5%, Sigma-Aldrich), ethanol (HPLC grade, Macklin), quinoline (98%, Alfa Aesar), Pt/C (5%, Alfa Aesar), all chemicals were used as received. 2.2 Synthesis of NaA zeolite and HA zeolite 11.5 g NaAlO2, 2.30 g NaOH and 3.54 g PEG were mixed with 28.0 g deionized water, and then stirred to form a clear solution. Next, 18.0 g of colloidal silica was slowly added into above clear solution under strong stirring condition. The obtained gel was prepared with molar composition of 1.56NaAlO2: 1.0SiO2: 0.64NaOH: 0.027 PEG: 24H2O. The gel was continued to stir for 30 min at room temperature, then subjected at 80 °C for 2 days in a teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The obtained solid was washed by filtration with deionized water followed by dried at 80 °C overnight to remove water. The dried powder was calcined at 400 °C for 2 h in static air to obtain the desired NaA zeolite. The obtained NaA zeolite was ion-exchanged in a 1.0 mol/L NH4Cl solution at 80 °C for 3 times, then followed by static air calcined at 400 °C for 2 h to obtain desired HA zeolite. 2.3 Synthesis of Pt@NaA catalyst The NaA zeolite encapsulated Pt clusters catalyst was prepared via ligand protected in situ hydrothermal method, in which chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O) and (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane were used as Pt precursor and corresponding ligand respectively. This ligand can prevent Pt precursor from precipitation under highly alkaline conditions during the synthesis of NaA zeolite, and favor precursor interactions with emerging incipient aluminosilicate moieties to facilitate precursor incorporation into A zeolite voids during the hydrothermal process [22–24]. After post processing processes including filtration, drying, calcination at 400 °C and reduction at 400 °C, NaA zeolite encapsulation of Pt clusters was obtained, denoted as Pt@NaA catalyst. Detailly, 2.30 g NaOH, 0.80 g (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane and 0.50 g H2PtCl6·6H2O were mixed with 12.0 g deionized water, and stirred to form a clear solution. Then, 3.54 g of PEG and 18.0 g of colloidal silica were added into above solution. The obtained solution was then heated in a water bath and kept at 80 °C under strong stirring condition until clear. 11.5 g NaAlO2 was dissolved in 16.0 g deionized water, and subsequently added into the above clear solution, stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The obtained gel was prepared with molar composition of 1.56NaAlO2: 1.0SiO2: 0.64NaOH: 0.027 PEG: 0.01H2PtCl6: 0.04(3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane: 24H2O and crystallized at 80 °C for 2 days. Afterwards, the obtained powder was washed by filtration with deionized water, then dried at 80 °C overnight. The dried sample was calcined at 400 °C for 2 h to remove organic components, followed by reduction at 400 °C for 4 h with flowing hydrogen to obtain encapsulated Pt@NaA catalyst. 2.4 Synthesis of encapsulated Pt@HA catalyst The obtained Pt@NaA catalyst was exchanged with NH4Cl three times, followed by calcination and reduction to afford desired Pt@HA catalyst. Detailly, the Pt@NaA catalyst before reduction was ion-exchanged in a 1.0 mol/L NH4Cl solution for 3 times. The obtained sample was calcination at 400 °C for 2 h, followed by hydrogen reduction at 400 °C for 4 h to obtain required encapsulated Pt@HA catalyst. 2.5 Synthesis of impregnated Pt/HA catalyst 0.12 g H2PtCl6·6H2O was dissolved with 60 mL H2O, then 3.0 g of HA zeolite was added into above solution. The mixture was stirred at 60 °C for 2 h, then centrifugation and dried at 80 °C to remove water. Next, the obtained sample was calcination at 400 °C for 2 h and reduction was carried out under hydrogen atmosphere at 400 °C for 4 h to obtain impregnated Pt/HA catalyst. 2.6 Hydrogenation of quinoline with hydrogen under batch reactor The hydrogenation reactions were conducted at a batch reactor. In a typical hydrogenation reaction, Pt@HA catalyst (26 mg), ethanol (3 mL), and quinoline (13 mg) were loaded into an autoclave. After being flushed with hydrogen three times, the reaction pressure in the autoclave was set to 2.0 MPa H2, and the reaction temperature was at 140 °C. The catalytic conversion and selectivity were determined by gas chromatograph (GC 8890, Agilent) equipped with flame ionization detector. For Pt/HA and Pt/C catalysts, the hydrogenation reaction was conducted under the same conditions, and the conversion was controlled to be > 98%. To measure the turnover frequency (TOF) in this transformation, the following formula was used: TOF = (Number of molecules reacted)/ (amounts of active sites of Pt) • (time). In which, (amounts of active sites) = (number of total amounts of Pt) • (dispersion of Pt nanoparticles on the zeolite support), and the dispersion of Pt nanoparticles on the zeolite support was calculated from the following equation [25,26]: D ( dispersion ) = 1 . 13 / d ( diameter , unit : nm ) where d is the average diameter of the PtNPs. 2.7 Hydrogenation of quinoline with deuterium under batch reactor The hydrogenation reaction was conducted under the same conditions as the hydrogenation of quinoline with hydrogen described above, except that hydrogen was replaced by deuterium. The reaction products were analyzed by GC analysis. 2.8 DFT calculation We calculated the ground state energy of quinoline and zeolite interaction using density functional theory (DFT) simulations at the stage of the quinoline molecule moves close to the Al-containing site and protonatsed acidic active site (H-site). Additionally, quinoline interacting with NaA was also calculated for comparison purposes. We employed B3LYP functional [27–30] combined with a def2-TZVP basis set [31,32]. The van der Waals correction method is Grimme's D3 [33,34]. All calculations were performed using the BDF software package[35–38] implemented in Device Studio, Version 2022B[39]. We constructed finite cluster models for the quinoline-HA interaction systems and incised a piece of the zeolite containing six metal atoms with alternating Si and Al atoms. The cut-off chain involves half of the eight-member ring and three halves of the nearby six-member ring. H atoms capped all the dangling O atoms. The O-sites on the eight-member ring and the six-member ring are also hydrogenated. The geometries of each structure were optimized by constraining the O atoms at the truncation edges and leaving all other atoms free to move. The Hessian matrices for each interaction structure were computed to determine the Gibbs free energies and thermal enthalpies. 2.9 Characterizations X-ray powder diffraction was conducted on the instrument model of Ultima IV equipped with a Cu target, operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Pt contents in catalysts were determined by ICP-MS analysis with an Agilent 7500CE instrument. 27Al MAS solid state NMR spectra were performed on a Bruker AVⅢ500 spectrometer equipped with a 44 mm HX MAS NMR probe. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) was performed on a JEM-3200FS from JEOL. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum TWO spectrometer. In situ diffuse reflectance FT-IR spectra of the adsorbed CO species were acquired with a Nicolet iS50 spectrometer at a spectral resolution of 4 cm−1 and with 32 scans. The sample powders were loaded into the IR cell, pretreated in pure H2 (3 mL/min) at 150 °C for 1 h at a heating rate of 0.8 °C/min, and then sustained at 100 °C in He (30 mL/min). The background spectrum was recorded under this condition. Then, after CO/He (1 vol%, 30 mL/min) introduced for 30 min, the sample was flushed with pure He (30 mL/min) before the spectra of chemisorbed CO were recorded. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were conducted on a Kratos AXIS ULtrabld spectrometer equipped with monochromatic Al Kα radiation. The binding energies were measured within the error of 0.05 eV. 1H NMR spectra was obtained on Bruker Ascend 600 spectrometer and the chemical shifts were referenced to deuterated chloroform. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of Pt@HA catalyst Powder X-ray diffraction was conducted to study the crystalline structures of prepared A zeolite (NaA and HA) encapsulated Pt clusters samples. Fig. 1 a showed that synthesized Pt@NaA exhibited similar X-ray diffraction peaks as parent NaA zeolite, suggesting that inclusion of the platinum precursor and the ligand into the sol-gel for A zeolite synthesis did not influence its crystallization process [40–44]. No observation of peaks corresponding to Pt nanoparticles and oxide indicated the absence of large platinum NPs in the A zeolite. For the Pt@HA sample, interestingly, a great loss of A zeolite crystallinity to cause zeolite amorphization was observed, as reported, which could be due to the collapsing of A zeolite framework upon NH4-exchanged process and following heat treatment. 27Al MAS NMR characterization further certified the occurrence of framework collapse in synthesized Pt@HA sample. As shown in Fig. 1b, Pt@NaA only showed single narrow peak in 27Al MAS NMR spectra at 60 ppm corresponding to tetrahedral Al site, yet, NH4-exchanged Pt@HA exhibited three peaks at 54, 30 and 0 p. p. m. in 27Al MAS NMR spectra, assigning to tetrahedral, penta-coordinated and octahedral Al sites respectively, clearly indicating the dealumination of A zeolite to make the framework collapse [45–47].As characterized by HAADF-STEM in Fig. 1c, the same as evenly distributed Pt clusters in NaA zeolite with average size of 1.22 nm (Figure S1), despite of zeolite amorphization, the size of encapsulated Pt clusters within HA zeolite remained around 0.93 nm, and Energy-disperse X-ray spectroscopy images in Figure S2 also demonstrated the homogeneous distribution of Pt clusters over the entire HA zeolite support. Moreover, the original cubic morphology of NaA crystallite were still retained for HA zeolite (Figure S3). These results suggested HA zeolite amorphization did not influence mean Pt size, but resulted in the short-range atomic rearrangements of the zeolite (dealumination) to afford amorphous aluminosilicate. The Pt content was around 1.57% as determined by ICP-MS analysis. As expected, in the FT-IR spectra in Fig. 1d, clear OH vibrational stretch at 3000–3800 cm−1 was observed in Pt@HA sample, yet a little invisible in Pt@NaA sample, indicating the NH4-exchange treatment resulting in the amorphization of A zeolite structure and generation of OH group, and as reported, these generated OH groups would be favor of hydrogen spillover process [48,49]. 3.2 Identification of the encapsulation of Pt clusters within HA zeolite To confirm whether Pt clusters encapsulated into amorphized HA zeolite or not, in situ DRIFT of CO adsorption characterization and XPS characterization were conducted over Pt@HA catalyst and Pt/HA catalyst (Pt nanoparticles impregnated into HA zeolite). As shown in Fig. 2 a, no CO adsorbed signal was observed over Pt@HA sample, suggesting that Pt clusters should be enclosed by the amorphous HA zeolite to prevent the diffusion of CO into such aluminosilicates to interact with encapsulated Pt clusters. Notably, the kinetic diameter of CO (0.37 nm) was smaller than the pore size of NaA zeolite with 0.4 nm, CO should diffuse into NaA zeolite to adsorb onto encapsulated Pt surface. In comparison, without detection of CO adsorption signal over Pt@HA also indicated that the amorphization of HA structure caused by NH4-exchange process and subsequent calcination treatment resulted in a less open aluminosilicate matrix and denser encapsulation of Pt clusters to limit the diffusion of CO, and this result was consistent with XRD characterization and 27Al MAS NMR characterization. Vibrational bands at typical 2067 cm−1 appeared clearly over Pt/HA catalyst, assigning to the linear CO bonded onto exposed Pt sites located at outer HA surfaces [50–52]. The results of XPS characterization also demonstrated the true encapsulation of Pt clusters into HA zeolite (Fig. 2b). The Pt/HA catalyst exhibited obvious peaks with the 4d5/2 and 4d3/2 components appearing at ∼314.8 and ∼331.5 eV of the binding energy, suggesting the detective Pt species located at the outer surface of HA zeolite [53]. Contrastly, with similar Pt contents to Pt/HA (1.50%), there is no observation of any XPS Pt 4d peak over Pt@HA catalyst, demonstrating the successful encapsulation very well. Significantly, aluminosilicate encapsulation can greatly promote the anti-sintering ability of Pt metals. As shown in Fig. 3 a, for the prepared HA zeolite encapsulation of Pt cluster, after calcination at 500 °C, Pt clusters were still distributed into A zeolite uniformly without observation of sintering and coalescence, and the statistical size of Pt clusters being 1.05 nm, which was very similar to that of fresh Pt@HA catalyst. After increasing calcination temperature to 600 °C, as characterized by HAADF-STEM in Fig. 3b, the average sizes of encapsulated Pt metals were still below 1.2 nm, certifying the very good thermal stability of encapsulated Pt metal in A zeolite during such harsh treatments. In contrast, for the Pt/HA catalyst with Pt metals located on external surface of zeolite, the statistical size of platinum NPs increased from 1.34 to 1.53 nm after only calcination 500 °C (Fig. S4, Fig. 3c). These results also proved the successful encapsulation of Pt clusters within A zeolite crystal, hence exhibiting great thermal stability. 3.3 Catalytic property of Pt@HA catalyst in hydrogenation of quinoline The catalytic property of Pt@HA catalyst and counterpart Pt/HA in selective hydrogenation of quinoline (1a) to 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline (2a) was studied, as shown in Fig. 4 a. Clearly, Pt@HA gave desired product 2a in more than 99% yield, along with approaching 100% catalytic selectivity in 240 min, showing the completely circumventing the formation of by-product of 3a (over-hydrogenation of benzene ring group). Particularly, even after the reactant 1a being totally consumed, further prolonging reaction time to 360 min, this remarkable selectivity could be maintained very well without detection any of byproduct 3a. This excellent selectivity should be valuable in view of practical industrial applications [54]. Additionally, as shown in Figure S5, increasing the temperature from 120 to 150 °C, the conversion of quinoline was not changed intensively, varied from 95% (120 °C) and 97% (130 °C) to approaching 100% (140 and 150 °C), while keeping the selectivity at around 99% very well. For the reaction concentration, varying solvent ethanol amount from 1 to 3 mL, the conversion of quinoline was kept at 97% (1 mL and 2 mL) and approaching 100% at 3 mL, along with the selectivity approaching 100%. While increasing the ethanol amount to 4 mL, the reaction conversion was slightly decreased to 94%, which could be due to the dilution effect (Figure S6). In contrast, for example, Pt/HA catalyst showed much lower catalytic selectivity to 2a (76%) at the conversion of 100% for reactant 1a, and over-hydrogenation products 3a were formed inevitably (Fig. 4b). Throughout the reaction, Pt/HA catalyst gave a lower yield of 2a with a maximum value of 76%, and over-hydrogenation byproduct formed during the reaction. Notably, although Pt/HA catalyst showed lower catalytic selectivity than that of Pt@HA in the hydrogenation of quinoline, the calculated TOF value of Pt/HA was up to 2037 h−1, which was higher than the TOF value of Pt@HA catalyst (65.36 h−1). Commercially available Pt/C catalysts also gave the very low catalytic selectivity to 2a with 58% at the 100% conversion of 1a. Additionally, the Pt@HA catalyst also exhibited good reusability for this hydrogenation reaction. As shown in Fig. 4c, after being used three times, no decrease of catalytic activity and selectivity was observed, and without coalescence or aggregation of Pt clusters was detected (Fig. 4d). Additionally, the Pt@HA catalyst showed excellent resistance to both acid and alkali treatment, for instance, even if the Pt@HA was treated with HF solution for 1 h, the catalytic selectivity to 2a can still remain at 98% without descend, indicating the very good protection of Pt clusters by dense aluminosilicate HA zeolite (Fig. S7). 3.4 Investigation of the catalytic mechanism of Pt@HA in the selective hydrogenation of quinoline to 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline To understand the critical role of zeolite encapsulation in the promotion of catalytic selectivity, several control experiments combined with DFT calculations were performed. In the case of amorphized HA zeolite encapsulation of Pt clusters system, due to pore diameter of HA zeolite even smaller than the molecule size of CO, quinoline with molecular size of around 0.73 nm should be forbidden to pass through micropore of HA zeolite to interact with encapsulated Pt clusters directly, hence avoiding both benzene moiety and pyridine moiety in one quinoline molecule being adsorbed on encapsulated Pt surface simultaneously. Such encapsulation implied that quinoline should be hydrogenated by spilled H species, which would be originated from the dissociation of H2 on the encapsulated Pt surface, and then migration of these activated H from Pt surface to HA zeolite surface through hydroxyl groups to finally afford spilled hydrogen species. The evidence of occurrence of hydrogen spillover was supported by the conducted experiment of reduction of physical mixed WO3 and Pt@HA catalyst [55,56]. The result in Figure S8 showed the successful reduction of yellow WO3 to light blue WO3-x, confirming the occurrence of hydrogen spillover. Therefore, either the benzene group or pyridine group in one quinoline molecule could be hydrogenated by spilled H species to give corresponding products respectively. Based on above analysis, the difference in activation energies of sole benzene group and sole pyridine groups in one quinoline molecule could be key in achieving the high selectivity. Given the structure character of quinoline molecules, symmetrical naphthalene with its molecular size larger than HA zeolite aperture was chosen as model substrate to simulate the benzene moiety hydrogenation process over Pt@HA catalyst, and symmetrical 1,8-naphthyridine also with larger molecular size than HA zeolite micropore was selected to simulate the pyridine moiety hydrogenation process over Pt@HA catalyst. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the hydrogenation of 1,8-naphthyridine could proceed easily over Pt@HA catalyst at 100, 110 and 120 °C with the calculated reaction rate being ∼0.247, ∼0.589 and ∼0.846 mol reactant consumed per mol of surface platinum per hour, respectively. Correspondingly, the apparent activation energy (E a) of Pt@HA for hydrogenation of 1,8-naphthyridine was calculated to be 74.88 kJ mol−1 (Figure S9). Whereas, hydrogenation of naphthalene over Pt@HA catalyst did not happen at all at the range of 100 to 120 °C with the reaction rate of zero, and even increasing reaction temperature to 180 °C, naphthalene still cannot be catalyzed (Fig. 5b). These results clearly indicated that the apparent E a of Pt@HA for the hydrogenation of 1,8-naphthyridine was much lower than that of E a for hydrogenation of naphthalene. Generally, E a is defined as the minimum amount of extra energy required by a reacting molecule to get converted into product [57,58]. Predictably, extra energy provided by the studied catalytic system in hydrogenation of quinoline cannot overcome the potential barrier for the hydrogenation of adsorbed benzene ring groups, but exceeding the potential-energy minimum for the hydrogenation of adsorbed pyridine ring group. Therefore, apparently, owing to the much lower E a of the Pt@HA catalyst for the hydrogenation of adsorbed pyridine groups than that of adsorbed benzene groups, this catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic selectivity in the present catalytic system. Detailed reaction mechanism was investigated to reveal the intrinsic meaning of obtained E a difference in hydrogenation of pyridine groups and benzene groups over Pt@HA catalyst through hydrogen spillover process. Typically, regarding spilled H hydrogenation process, the reaction steps usually including the reactant (e.g. quinoline) adsorbed onto zeolite external surface and H2 diffusion into zeolite pore to interact with encapsulated Pt clusters, then activation of H2 on Pt surface, migration of active H atoms from Pt surface to adjacent zeolite, diffusion of active H atoms throughout the zeolite to its external surface, and reaction of spilled H with adsorbed reactant to give hydrogenation product [18,59]. Initially, the role of hydrogen in this selective hydrogenation quinoline was studied with H2-D2 exchange experiment (Fig. 6 a). As shown, secondary isotope effect was observed with the ratio of hydrogenation reaction rates (k H/k D) calculated to be 1.34, less than the value of 1.5, suggesting that H2 diffusion, H2 dissociation on encapsulated Pt surface, long-range diffusion of active H atoms throughout the zeolite to its external surface, dissociated hydrogen species reacted with adsorbed activated quinoline should not involve into the rate-determination step to influence E a largely [60]. The effect of H2 pressure on catalytic property of Pt@HA catalyst in hydrogenation of quinoline within 1 h was investigated. As shown in Fig. 6b, the conversion of quinoline stayed around 85% without largely increasing on elevating hydrogen pressure from 2 to 3 MPa, implying very weak influence of H2 pressure on this hydrogenation reaction, which was consistent with H2-D2 exchange experiment. Since exclusion of the possibility of H involved into the rate-determination step, the remaining step of quinoline adsorbed onto HA zeolite external surface was investigated. Similarly, naphthalene was chosen as model substrate to simulate the benzene moiety adsorption, and 1,8-naphthyridine was selected to simulate the pyridine moiety adsorption over Pt@HA catalyst. After exposure of the Pt@HA catalysts to naphthalene, 1,8-naphthyridine and the mixture of naphthalene and 1,8-naphthyridine respectively, then subsequent removal of physisorbed above molecules, the catalysts were subjected to 1H NMR characterization analysis. As shown in Fig. 7 a, signals of naphthalene and 1,8-naphthyridine were observed from the sample of exposure of the Pt@HA catalyst to naphthalene and the sample of exposure of the Pt@HA catalyst to 1,8-naphthyridine, respectively, indicating the successful adsorption of these molecules onto HA zeolite external surface. Interestingly, for the sample of exposure of the Pt@HA catalyst to the mixture of naphthalene and 1,8-naphthyridine, only signal of 1,8-naphthyridine was observed, suggesting the 1,8-naphthyridine preferring to adsorb on the HA surface for a larger adsorption energy in the presence of naphthalene and 1,8-naphthyridine. Notably, unfortunately, observation of the formation of NH bond between quinoline and Pt@HA catalyst through FT-IR and Raman characterizations has not been successful. However, it is known that pyridine can strongly interaction with -OH group (Bronsted acid) in zeolite through the formation of NH bond [61,62]. Presumably, as literature reported, quinoline molecule with the pyridine ring also could be interaction with -OH group (Bronsted acid) through the formation of NH bond to make it adsorb on HA zeolite stably [63]. DFT calculation demonstrated that the existence of OH group in zeolite HA could facilitate the interaction of quinoline with HA surface very well. The model of used DFT calculation method was referred from reported literatures [18,20]. As shown in Fig. 7b, the interaction enthalpy change ( Δ H int ) for quinoline interacting with the protonated acidic center (H-site) is in the middle between quinoline adsorbs on the Al-site of HA and on the Na-site of NaA. Here, N atom on the quinoline was major interacting site as N was more electronegative compared to other C-containing sites and exhibited large charge density tending to donate electrons to the active site on the zeolite. (HOMO diagram and energetics are shown in Figure S10) Thermodynamically, quinoline favored the Al-site to form a stable adsorption structure (Fig. 7b). However, the NH bond formation occurred almost spontaneously as the quinoline molecule moved closer to the H-site (see Fig. 7c). Such a moderate interaction of this newly formed species could lead to easy desorption and assist the further reaction to progress. Furthermore, the calculated Gibbs free energy change indicated that the quinoline interacting with all sites are spontaneous at the room temperature and follow the same trend as Δ H int . The H-site interaction was still in the middle (ΔG = -66.21 kJ mol−1 seeing Table S1). The consistent trend in ΔH and ΔG indicated the entropy change during these processes was not significant. In other words, the kinetic effect was not essential in these processes. Therefore, we can rationalize that quinoline adsorbs at the H-site of HA was the rate limiting step during the catalytic cycle. In comparison with Pt@NaA catalyst with less hydroxyl groups at surface to give TOF value of 25.16 h−1, Pt@HA exhibited higher TOF value with 65.36 h−1 further certified the critical role of hydroxyl groups at HA zeolite support to strengthen the adsorption of quinoline on HA to promote the catalytic performance in this hydrogenation reaction (Figure S11). Reasonably, at the rate-determination step of quinoline adsorbed onto HA zeolite surface, attributed to the stronger adsorption energy of pyridine moiety on Pt@HA catalyst surface than that of benzene moiety, Pt@HA achieved a very high catalytic selectivity in hydrogenation of quinoline to desired 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline through hydrogen spillover process. 3.5 Scope and limitation of Pt@HA catalyst Significantly, Pt@HA catalyst also exhibited very good substrate compatibility (Table 1 ). In addition to quinoline (entry 1), indole and isoquinoline were hydrogenated regioselectively to afford the desired products in high catalytic selectivity and in high yield very well (entry 2 and 3). Quinolines bearing methyl group at meta-site (entry 4) and ortho-site (entry 5) were also suitable for this present hydrogenation system, giving the corresponding tetrahydroquinolines in excellent yields with approaching 100% selectivity. In the case of 6-fluoroquinoline, the Pt@HA catalyst displayed satisfactory catalytic performance, providing the corresponding products in more than 90% yield (entry 6). Attractively, an interesting chemoselectivity toward the selective hydrogenation of pyridine group was observed with starting material containing reducible CCl bond on the benzene ring (6-chloroquinoline as reactant in entry 7), affording the desired hydrogen product in high yield without significant over-reduction to form the dehalogenated byproduct. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, the present amorphized HA zeolite encapsulated Pt clusters catalyst (Pt@HA) exhibited remarkable catalytic selectivity in the selective hydrogenation of quinoline throughout the transformation, and accompanied with good reusability and substrate compatibility. This excellent catalytic selectivity was originated from the “insulation” effect of HA zeolite to prevent the direct interaction of encapsulated Pt clusters with quinoline reactants, and making the quinolines be hydrogenated by spilled active H species. Attributed to the much lower apparent activation energy of Pt@HA for hydrogenation of pyridine moiety than that of benzene moiety, spilled active H species preferred to react with pyridine moiety to give desired product, and avoiding the over-hydrogenation of benzene moiety. Controlled experiments combined with DFT calculation revealed that generated hydroxyl groups at surface of HA zeolite to facilitate the adsorption of pyridine moiety onto Pt@HA catalyst through the formation NH bond to strengthen the spillover hydrogenation step played the critical role to lower the apparent activation energy of Pt@HA for hydrogenation of pyridine moiety. These findings enrich the hydrogen spillover theory through the further exploring of support role to strengthen the spillover hydrogenation step, which will benefit to design advanced heterogeneous catalysts with enhanced catalytic activity and selectivity. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen spillover has been widely used in heterogeneous catalysis, yet how to explore the potential of catalyst support to further promote catalytic function of hydrogen spillover has rarely been investigated. Herein, platinum encapsulated into amorphized HA zeolite (denoted as Pt@HA) with generated hydroxyl groups was used as model catalyst to study the role of HA zeolite support on the promotion of catalytic performance in hydrogenation of quinolines to tetrahydroquinolines. Benefiting from small pore size of amorphized HA zeolite to prevent direct interaction of quinoline with encapsulated platinum, Pt@HA showed good catalytic selectivity in this transformation through hydrogen spillover. This remarkable catalytic selectivity was resulted from the interaction of hydroxyl groups at surface of HA zeolite with pyridine moiety through the formation NH bond to facilitate adsorption to make much lower apparent activation energy of Pt@HA for hydrogenation of pyridine moiety than that of benzene moiety, thus exhibiting enhanced catalytic selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Strengthening spillover hydrogenation of quinoline compounds over platinum-encapsulated amorphized HA zeolite catalyst
